utterances.text: hi this is a really great question
so let's talk about it
this is gonna be part Ⅰ of my video series on freedom of religion in China
if you wanna watch any of the other videos in this series
you can click on the playlist below
so here's something that often surprises people
freedom of religion is in china's constitution
chapter 2 article 36
right here so let's read it
article 36 citizens of the people's republic of china shall enjoy
freedom of religious belief
no state organization
or individual
shall coerce citizens to believe in or not to believe in any religion
nor shall they discriminate against citizens who believe in
or do not believe in any religion
the state shall protect normal religious activities
no one shall use religion to engage in activities that disrupt public order
impair the health of citizens
or interfere with the state's education system
religious groups and religious affairs
shall not be subject to control by foreign forces
sounds like they have complete freedom of religion
what's the issue
well here's the thing when it comes to government restrictions on religion
china's score is really really high
wait a minute
wait a minute
we just read a whole section in china's constitution
that talks about religious freedom
and yet the government has these strict restrictions on religion
doesn't that conflict with each other
well no
it all has to do with the wording of the constitution
here's a key sentence I want you
to remember the state shall protect normal religious activities
so who gets to define what's normal the state
and that's where we're going to see these religious restrictions
the state only officially recognizes five religions islam buddhism
taoism catholicism
and protestantism
now there's a lot of other religions present within China
especially some traditional Chinese beliefs
while these are not officially recognized by the state
for the most part
they are tolerated
an example of a religion that is pretty widespread in China
but isn't official would be judaism
there's a lot of jewish people in China
I have a video about the Kaifeng jews for example
and there's lots of jewish people in Shanghai
but judaism is not a religion that's officially recognized by the state
religious organizations have to register with one of these five state recognized
religions
and all of this is going to be overseen by the united front work department
within those state recognized religions
there's state recognized organizations
and this is something that's also really difficult with religious freedom
christianity for example
protestantism
that's just an overall
like label there's all kinds of branches beneath that like baptists
methodists non nomination episcopalian
so while you will see big super churches like the Chongyi church in hangzhou
and I mean super churches
this church is huge
they have to register with state recognized organizations
